title: Catholicism and other denominations in the South
content: According to Edward Ayers, religion was a Southerner's way of life and they
often justified or condemned something based on religion. Myriad Christian
denominations were active in the South including Baptist, Episcopal, Methodist,
Catholic, Lutheran, Protestant, and Quaker, however; the Baptist denomination claimed
the largest following. The Norfolk Virginian, like other newspapers, would often publish
articles concerning religious aspects of the community. On August 13, 1890, the paper
included and article about Pope Leo XIII giving a worldwide decree permitting Catholics
to eat meat on Friday the August 15, 1890, which was usually not allowed, because it was
the Feast of Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary. One of the oldest religions in the
United States was Catholicism, which had existed in the South since colonial times
brought over by the Europeans. In the United States, Catholicism remained a minority,
which Virginia's religious population mirrored. The Norfolk Virginian made this obvious
in its article, which was written as if the reader had no prior knowledge of what Catholics
believed.
Catholicism was often scorned by other denominations as too structured, and the
other congregations also questioned the validity of an infallible and foreign leader, the
Pope. From the 1880s to the 1920s Catholicism contributed to the tension that was
dubbed Nativism, according to the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture. Nativists believed
that immigrants were the cause of social and economic problems in the United States. For
example, immigrants were willing to work for lower wages, thus prompting a
competition for jobs between the two groups. During this period many immigrants came
to the United States, and most of them were Catholic. According to the Encyclopedia of
Religion in the South, Nativists correlated Catholicism with immigrants, thus there were
tensions between Catholics and other congregations, especially the Baptist who called the
Catholic Church the mother of harlots, and also a tyrannical institution that kept its
people in ignorance. This belief was less severe in Virginia in comparison, but was
nonetheless present.
Religion was racially segregated in the South. Blacks, after emancipation mostly
formed their own churches and programs. The main denomination for blacks was Baptist;
by 1900, there were 200,000 black Baptists in Virginia that contributed to the 1.3 million
members in the South. Another large congregation for blacks was Methodist with a
reported 30,000 members in the state. In this aspect, Virginia definitely followed the rest
of the South. Despite the racial segregation, relations between black and white churches
were still friendly. According to the Encyclopedia of Religion in the South, the southern
Whites still had a paternalistic attitude toward their coreligionists and had a hand, along
with northern missionaries, in establishing the separate congregations. In addition, white
Christians in groups such as Society of Friends, the Methodist Episcopal Church, and the
United Presbyterian Church helped establish schools for Blacks, and some white Baptists
also became trustees of the black school in Richmond, according to the Encyclopedia of
Religion in the South.
Churches not only contributed to black education, but also to the education of the
population in general since public high schools were not common. According to the
Encyclopedia of Religion in the South, the Baptists operated fifteen schools for boys and
eighteen schools for girls during the 1890's in Virginia, and other denominations also
established schools. Christians also worked on obtaining higher education for women,
and either established separate colleges for them such as the Randolph-Macon Woman's
College in Lynchburg, Virginia in 1893, or permitted admission into preexisting colleges
such as the Richmond College in Richmond, Virginia in 1898. However, there were still
a few southerners against this because they still viewed the domestic sphere as the proper
place for women.
